templates.title: Hyndburn Leisure Trust Subsidy History
templates.why: The Hyndburn Leisure Trust has reportedly lost money every year since its formation, receiving approximately £1 million per year in council subsidy. With a £12 million capital investment now planned for Wilson's Playing Field, residents deserve full transparency on the Trust's financial track record.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding Hyndburn Leisure Trust:

1. The total annual subsidy or management fee paid by Hyndburn Borough Council to Hyndburn Leisure Trust for each financial year since the Trust's formation, broken down by revenue support and any capital contributions
2. Total annual visitor numbers for all Leisure Trust facilities for each year since formation
3. The calculated cost per visit for each year (total subsidy divided by total visits)
4. The Leisure Trust's annual accounts or financial statements for each year since formation, including any operating deficits
5. The full business case, feasibility study, or options appraisal for the proposed new facility at Wilson's Playing Field, including the £12 million capital cost estimate
6. Any independent assessment or due diligence review of the Leisure Trust's ability to operate a new facility without increasing the annual subsidy
7. Details of any performance targets or KPIs set for the Trust and whether they have been met
templates.context: Hyndburn Leisure Trust has reportedly required approximately £1 million per year in council subsidy since formation, while consistently operating at a loss. The council is now proposing a £12 million capital investment for a new leisure facility at Wilson's Playing Field. Understanding the Trust's financial history is essential before committing further public money.

templates.title: Morgan Sindall Regeneration Contract
templates.why: The regeneration contract with Morgan Sindall has been reported at values between £60 million and £70 million. The £10 million variance is unexplained and the SCAPE framework procurement route raises questions about competitive tension.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding the council's regeneration contract with Morgan Sindall:

1. The original contract value agreed with Morgan Sindall, and an explanation of why publicly reported figures vary between £60 million and £70 million
2. A schedule of all contract variations, change orders, or additional works agreed since the original contract was signed, with the value of each
3. The current total committed spend under the contract as of the date of this request
4. A breakdown of costs for Phase 2 of the regeneration programme, including individual project costs
5. The fees paid to the SCAPE framework for the procurement of this contract, expressed as both a percentage and absolute value
6. Whether a competitive procurement process was considered as an alternative to the SCAPE framework, and if so, the reasons SCAPE was preferred
7. All performance reports or progress updates submitted by Morgan Sindall in the last 12 months
8. Any independent value-for-money assessments conducted on this contract
templates.context: The Morgan Sindall regeneration contract is one of the largest single contracts in Hyndburn's history at £60-70 million. The use of the SCAPE framework bypasses traditional competitive tendering. The £10 million variance in publicly reported contract values is significant and unexplained. Understanding the true cost and fee structure is essential for public accountability.

templates.title: Huncoat Garden Village Consultancy Costs
templates.why: Huncoat Garden Village is a £463 million development project. Major consultancy firms Arcadis and Avison Young have been engaged, but the total fees paid are not publicly transparent.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding the Huncoat Garden Village project:

1. The total fees paid to Arcadis in connection with Huncoat Garden Village, broken down by financial year and by type of work (e.g. masterplanning, project management, engineering, environmental)
2. The total fees paid to Avison Young in connection with Huncoat Garden Village, broken down by financial year and by type of work (e.g. viability assessment, land valuation, development advice)
3. The total fees paid to all other external consultants, advisors, or contractors in connection with the project, listed by firm name and amount
4. Total internal project management costs including staff time allocated to the project
5. The current project risk register, or if exempt, a summary of the top 10 risks by financial impact
6. Any independent gateway reviews or project assurance reports commissioned for the project
7. The total public sector funding committed or spent on the project to date, broken down by source (council funds, Homes England, other grants)
templates.context: Huncoat Garden Village is a £463 million development that would transform a significant area of Hyndburn. Projects of this scale typically incur substantial consultancy costs. Understanding how much has been spent on professional fees before any homes are built helps assess whether the project is being managed cost-effectively.

templates.title: Three Years of Unaudited Accounts
templates.why: Hyndburn Borough Council's accounts for 2022/23 and 2023/24 both received a 'disclaimer of opinion' from the external auditor, meaning the auditor could not confirm whether the accounts were accurate. Three consecutive years without a clean audit opinion is a serious governance failure.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding the council's financial audit position:

1. The external auditor's management letters (also known as ISA 260 reports or 'Report to Those Charged with Governance') for the financial years 2021/22, 2022/23, and 2023/24
2. The specific reasons given by the external auditor for issuing a disclaimer of opinion for 2022/23 and 2023/24
3. All internal audit reports completed during the period 2021/22 to 2024/25, or if this volume is too large, a list of all internal audit reports with their titles, dates, and assurance ratings
4. The council's formal response or action plan addressing the issues raised in each disclaimer of opinion
5. Any correspondence between the council and the external auditor regarding the audit delays or disclaimer opinions
6. The fees paid to the external auditor for each of the last three financial years
7. The current status and expected completion date for the 2024/25 accounts and audit
templates.context: A disclaimer of opinion is the most serious outcome of a financial audit, meaning the auditor was unable to obtain sufficient evidence to form a view on whether the accounts are accurate. Two consecutive disclaimer opinions at Hyndburn (2022/23 and 2023/24) suggest systemic issues with financial record-keeping or governance. This is not part of the national audit backlog issue -- it represents a specific failure at Hyndburn.

templates.title: Executive Pay and Pay Multiple
templates.why: Residents should be able to see how senior executive pay compares to the lowest-paid council staff and to similar councils. The pay multiple ratio is a key measure of proportionality.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding senior officer pay:

1. The Pay Policy Statement for 2025/26 (or the most recent version if 2025/26 is not yet published)
2. The total remuneration package for the Chief Executive, including base salary, employer pension contributions, any performance-related pay, bonuses, and benefits in kind
3. The total remuneration for all officers earning over £50,000 per annum, listed by post title (not officer name)
4. The pay multiple ratio between the Chief Executive's total remuneration and the median earnings of all council employees
5. The pay multiple ratio between the Chief Executive's total remuneration and the lowest-paid full-time equivalent employee
6. Any changes to senior officer pay or structure since April 2023, including any posts created, deleted, or regraded
7. Benchmarking data used by the council to set senior pay, including any comparator councils referenced
templates.context: Councils are required to publish annual Pay Policy Statements under the Localism Act 2011, but these often lack the detail needed to fully understand senior pay arrangements. The pay multiple ratio (highest to median and highest to lowest) is a key indicator of pay fairness. National data shows significant variation in chief executive pay across district councils.

templates.title: Supported Exempt Accommodation Costs
templates.why: Hyndburn reportedly loses approximately £1 million per year in Housing Benefit subsidy through Supported Exempt Accommodation claims. Nationally, this sector has been plagued by abuse, with poor-quality providers claiming enhanced Housing Benefit for minimal or non-existent 'support'.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding Supported Exempt Accommodation in Hyndburn:

1. A list of all providers currently claiming Housing Benefit for Supported Exempt Accommodation in the borough, including their organisation name and legal entity type (registered charity, CIC, limited company, etc.)
2. The total Housing Benefit paid to each provider for Supported Exempt Accommodation for each financial year from 2021/22 to 2024/25
3. The total Housing Benefit subsidy loss to the council arising from Supported Exempt Accommodation claims for each of those years (i.e. the difference between HB paid and government subsidy received)
4. Whether each provider is registered with the Charity Commission, and if so, their charity registration number
5. Any quality assessments, inspections, or reviews of support provision carried out by the council on exempt accommodation providers in the last three years
6. The number of properties used as Supported Exempt Accommodation in the borough, broken down by provider
7. Any referrals made to the Regulator of Social Housing or other bodies regarding concerns about exempt accommodation providers
8. The council's current policy or strategy for managing the growth of exempt accommodation
templates.context: Supported Exempt Accommodation allows Housing Benefit to be claimed at significantly higher rates than standard housing, provided the landlord offers 'care, support, or supervision' to vulnerable tenants. Nationally, this sector has grown rapidly, with numerous reports of abuse where providers claim enhanced Housing Benefit while offering minimal support. The estimated £1 million annual subsidy loss to Hyndburn represents a significant financial burden on the council and ultimately on local council tax payers.

templates.title: Council Tax Collection Performance
templates.why: Hyndburn's council tax collection rate has been reported as below the peer average. Understanding the scale of arrears, enforcement costs, and trends helps assess whether the collection strategy is effective.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding council tax collection:

1. The in-year council tax collection rate for each financial year from 2019/20 to 2024/25
2. The total outstanding council tax arrears as at 31 March for each of those years
3. The amount of council tax debt written off as irrecoverable for each of those years
4. The total cost of council tax recovery and enforcement for each year, including staff costs, court costs, and any fees paid to external enforcement agents or bailiffs
5. The number of liability orders obtained by the council for each year
6. The number of cases referred to enforcement agents (bailiffs) for each year, and the total debt recovered through this route
7. Any benchmarking data comparing Hyndburn's collection rate with CIPFA nearest neighbours or other Lancashire districts
8. Whether the council has considered or implemented any alternative approaches to debt recovery, such as the Council Tax Protocol or vulnerability screening
templates.context: Council tax is the single largest source of locally-raised income for most district councils. Below-average collection rates mean less income to fund services. High enforcement costs can offset the benefit of aggressive collection. Understanding the full picture -- collection rates, arrears levels, write-offs, and enforcement costs -- is essential to assess whether the council's approach is effective and proportionate.

templates.title: Waste Disposal Costs and Strategy
templates.why: Hyndburn does not have its own waste transfer station, meaning waste must be transported to Farington or other facilities. This adds significant cost. With food waste collection becoming mandatory, the financial implications could be substantial.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding waste disposal:

1. The total annual cost of waste disposal (excluding collection) for each financial year from 2021/22 to 2024/25, broken down by waste type (residual, dry recycling, green waste, bulky waste)
2. Any options appraisal or feasibility study conducted regarding the provision of a waste transfer station within the borough
3. The cost of transporting waste to the Farington facility (or any other transfer station), including vehicle costs, fuel, staff time, and gate fees
4. Cost modelling for a scenario where Farington is the only available disposal point, including the impact on collection rounds and transport costs
5. The council's implementation plan for the introduction of mandatory food waste collection, including estimated capital and revenue costs
6. Whether the council has explored shared service arrangements with neighbouring authorities for waste transfer or disposal
7. The current contract arrangements for waste disposal, including the contractor name, contract value, and expiry date
8. The council's current recycling rate and how this compares to the national target and Lancashire district average
templates.context: The lack of a local waste transfer station means Hyndburn's waste must travel further for processing, adding transport costs that neighbouring councils with their own facilities do not face. The introduction of mandatory food waste collection will add a new waste stream that requires separate processing. Without proper planning and cost modelling, these combined pressures could significantly increase the waste budget.

templates.title: Local Government Reorganisation Preparation Costs
templates.why: Lancashire is undergoing local government reorganisation. The costs of preparing for this transition should be transparent, as they come from existing council budgets at a time when services are already under financial pressure.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request the following information regarding local government reorganisation (LGR) preparations:

1. The total amount spent by Hyndburn Borough Council on local government reorganisation preparations to date, broken down by category (consultancy, legal advice, staff costs, IT, communications, etc.)
2. A list of all external consultants or advisors engaged in connection with LGR, including their fees and the scope of work
3. The amount of senior officer and member time allocated to LGR activity, expressed as an estimated cost
4. Any budget allocated specifically for LGR-related activity in 2025/26 and future years
5. How LGR preparation costs are being funded -- from reserves, existing budgets, or borrowing
6. Any impact assessments on how reorganisation may affect current council services or staff
7. Copies of any submissions made by the council to MHCLG or other bodies regarding the preferred reorganisation option
templates.context: Local government reorganisation in Lancashire will replace the current two-tier system of county and district councils. While the outcome may deliver long-term savings, the transition process itself will cost money. Similar reorganisation exercises elsewhere have cost millions. Understanding what Hyndburn is spending on preparation helps residents assess whether costs are being managed appropriately during a period of significant financial pressure.

rights: Anyone can make an FOI request -- you don't need to give a reason
The council must respond within 20 working days
Information should be free, though the council can charge for printing
If refused, you can request an internal review
If still unsatisfied, you can appeal to the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO)
tips: Be specific -- vague requests are easier to refuse
Ask for documents, not opinions or explanations
Reference specific time periods (e.g. 'from April 2021 to March 2025')
If you know a specific document exists, ask for it by name
Keep requests focused on one topic for faster responses
